div.head: Introduction
div.p: THIS play — originally intended to form part of Angels and Ministers — was separated on an after-thought as a concession to those who do not like to have their politics and their religion mixed . And , as the Victorian age was eminently successful in keeping the two apart , it is ‘ in keeping , ’ in another sense , with the Victorianism of the religion here portrayed that it should make its appearance under a separate cover .

As some of my critics seem anxious to trace the inspiration of these Victorian plays to an outside source , and are divided , as regards the historical section , between the Abraham Lincoln of Mr. John Drinkwater and the Queen Victoria of Mr. Lytton Strachey , may I assure them that my historical method of treating Kings and Queens ‘ intimately ’ was derived from my own play Pains and Penalties , published in 1911 , and that my anthropomorphic theology is based upon the first book I ever wrote , Gods and their Makers , published in 1897 . I do not think that Possession owes anything either to Cranford or the writings of Mrs. Humphry Ward .

set.p: SCENE .— The Everlasting Habitations It is evening ( or so it seems ) , and to the comfortably furnished Victorian drawing-room a middle-aged maid-servant in cap and apron brings a lamp , and proceeds to draw blinds and close curtains . To do this she passes the fire-place , where before a pleasantly bright hearth sits , comfortably sedate , an elderly lady whose countenance and attitude suggest the very acme of genteel repose . She is a handsome woman , very conscious of herself , but carrying the burden of her importance with an ease which , in her own mind , leaves nothing to be desired . The once-striking outline of her features has been rounded by good feeding to a softness which is merely physical ; and her voice , when she speaks , has a calculated gentleness very caressing to her own ear , and a little irritating to others who are not of an inferior class . Menials like it , however . The room , though over-upholstered , and not furnished with any more individual taste than that which gave its generic stamp to the great Victorian period , is the happy possessor of some good things . Upon the mantel-shelf , backed by a large mirror , stands old china in alternation with alabaster jars , under domed shades , and tall vases encompassed by pendant ringlets of glass-lustre . Rose-wood , walnut , and mahogany make a well-wooded interior ; and in the dates thus indicated there is a touch of Georgian . But , over and above these mellowing features of a respectable ancestry , the annunciating Angel of the Great Exhibition of 1851 has spread a brooding wing . And while the older articles are treasured on account of family association , the younger and newer stand erected in places of honour by reason of an intrinsic beauty never previously attained to . Through this chamber the dashing crinoline has wheeled the too vast orb of its fate , and left fifty years after ( if we may measure the times of Heaven by the ticks of an earthly chronometer ) a mark which nothing is likely to erase . Upon the small table , where Hannah the servant deposits the lamp , lies a piece of crochet-work . The fair hands that have been employed on it are folded on a lap of corded silk representing the fashions of the nineties , and the grey-haired beauty ( that once was ) sits contemplative , wearing a cap of creamish lace , tastefully arranged , not unaware that in the entering lamp-light , and under the fire 's soft glow of approval , she presents to her domestic 's eye an improving picture of gentility . It is to Miss Julia Robinson 's credit — and she herself places it there emphatically — that she always treats servants humanly , though at a distance . And when she now speaks she confers her slight remark just a little as though it were a favour .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: How the days are drawing out , Hannah .

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: Yes , Ma'am ; nicely , are n't they ?

body.stage: For Hannah , being old-established , may say a thing or two not in the strict order . In fact , it may be said that , up to a well-understood point , character is encouraged in her , and is allowed to peep through in her remarks .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What time is it ? HANNAHlooking with better eyes than her mistress at the large ormolu clock which records eternally the time of the great ExhibitionAlmost a quarter to six , Ma'am .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: So late ? She ought to have been here long ago .

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: Who , Ma'am , did you say , Ma'am ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: My sister , Mrs. James . You remember ?

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: What , Miss Martha , Ma'am ? Well !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: No , it 's Miss Laura this time : you did n't know she had married , I suppose ? HANNAHwith a world of meaning , well under controlNo , Ma'am .A pause .I made up the bed in the red room ; was that right , Ma'am ? JULIAarchly surprisedWhat ? Then you knew someone was coming ? Why did you pretend , Hannah ?

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: Well , Ma'am , you see , you had n't told me before .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I could n't . One cannot always be sure .This mysteriously .But something tells me now that she is to be with us . I have been expecting her over four days . HANNAHpicking her phrases a little , as though on doubtful groundIt must be a long way , Ma'am . Did she make a comfortable start , Ma'am ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Very quietly , I 'm told . No pain .

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: I wonder what she 'll be able to eat now , Ma'am . She was always very particular .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I daresay you will be told soon enough .Thus in veiled words she conveys that Hannah knows something of Mrs. James 's character .HANNAHresignedlyYes , M 'm .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I do n't think I 'll wait any longer . If you 'll bring in tea now . Make enough for two , in case : pour it off into another pot , and have it under the tea-cosy .

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: Yes , Ma'am .

body.stage: Left alone , the dear lady enjoys the sense of herself and the small world of her own thoughts in solitude . Then she sighs indulgently .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Yes , I suppose I would rather it had been Martha . Poor Laura !She puts out her hand for her crochet , when it is arrested by the sound of a knock , rather rapacious in character .Ah , that 's Laura all over !Seated quite composedly and fondling her well-kept hands , she awaits the moment of arrival . Very soon the door opens , and the over-expected Mrs. James — a luxuriant garden of widow 's weeds , enters . She is a lady more strongly and sharply featured than her sister , but there is nothing thin-lipped about her ; with resolute eye and mouth a little grim , yet pleased at so finding herself , she steps into this chamber of old memories and cherished possessions , which translation to another and a better world has made hers again . For a moment she sees the desire of her eyes and is satisfied ; but for a moment only . The apparition of another already in possession takes her aback .JULIAwith soft effusivenessWell , Laura ! LAURAstartledJulia !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Here you are !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Whoever thought of finding you ? JULIAsweetlyDid n't you ?

body.stage: They have managed to embrace : but Laura continues to have her grievance .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No ! not for a moment . I really think they might have told me . What brought you ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Our old home , Laura . It was a natural choice , I think : as one was allowed to choose . I suppose you were ? LAURAher character showingI did n't ask anyone 's leave to come .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And how are you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I do n't know ; I want my tea .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Hannah is just bringing it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Who 's Hannah ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Our Hannah : our old servant . Did n't she open the door to you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What ? Come back , has she ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I found her here when I came , seven years ago . I did n't ask questions . Here she is .ENTER Hannah with the tea-tray .LAURAwith a sort of grim jocosityHow d'ye do , Hannah ?

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: Nicely , thank you , Ma'am . How are you , Ma'am ?

body.stage: Hannah , as she puts down the tray , is prepared to have her hand shaken : for it is a long time ( thirty years or so in earthly measure ) since they met . But Mrs. James is not so cordial as all that .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm very tired .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You 've come a long way .

body.stage: But Laura 's sharp attention has gone elsewhere .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Hannah , what have you got my best tray for ? You know that is not to be used every day .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It 's all right , Laura . You do n't understand .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What do n't I understand ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Here one always uses the best . Nothing wears out or gets broken .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then where 's the pleasure of it ? If one always uses them and they never break — ‘ best ’ means nothing !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It is a little puzzling at first . You must be patient .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm not a child , Julia . JULIAbeautifully ignoringA little more coal , please , Hannah .Then to her sister as she pours out the tea .And how did you leave everybody ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , pretty much as usual . Most of them having colds . That 's how I got mine . Mrs. Hilliard came to call and left it behind her . I went out with it in an east wind and that finished me .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , but how provoking !She wishes to be sympathetic ; but this is a line of conversation she instinctively avoids .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , Julia ! . . .This , delivered with force , arrests the criminal intention .No sugar . To think of your forgetting that ! JULIAmost sweetlyMilk ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , you know I take milk .

body.stage: Crossing over , but sitting away from the tea-table , she lets her sister wait on her .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Did Martha send me any message ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How could she ? She did n't know I was coming .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Was it so sudden ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I sent for her and she did n't come . Think of that !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh ! She would be sorry . Tea-cake ? LAURAtaking the tea-cake that is offered herI 'm not so sure . She was nursing Edwin 's boy through the measles , so of course I did n't count .Nosing suspiciously .Is this China tea ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: If you like to think it . You have as you choose . How is our brother , Edwin ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: His wife 's more trying than ever . Julia , what a fool that woman is !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Well , let 's hope he does n't know it .

lg.l: He must know . I 've told him . She sent a wreath to my funeral ,
‘ With love and fond affection , from Emily . ’ Fond fiddlesticks ! Humbug !
She knows I can n't abide her .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I suppose she thought it was the correct thing .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: And I doubt if it cost more than ten shillings . Now Mrs. Dobson — you remember her : she lives in Tudor Street with a daughter one never sees — something wrong in her head , and has fits — she sent me a cross of lilies , white lilac , and stephanotis , as handsome as you could wish ; and a card — I forget what was on the card . . . . Julia , when you died ——

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , do n't Laura !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , you did die , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Here one does n't talk of it . That 's over . There are things you will have to learn .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What I was going to say was — when I died I found my sight was much better . I could read all the cards without my glasses . Do you use glasses ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Sometimes , for association . I have these of our dear Mother 's in her tortoise-shell case .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That reminds me . Where is our Mother ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She comes — sometimes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why is n't she here always ? JULIAwith pained sweetnessI do n't know , Laura . I never ask questions .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Really , Julia , I shall be afraid to open my mouth presently ! JULIAlong-suffering stillWhen you see her you will understand . I told her you were coming , so I daresay she will look in .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: ‘ Look in ’ !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Perhaps . That is her chair , you remember . She always sits there , still .ENTER Hannah with the coal .Just a little on , please , Hannah — only a little .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: This is n't China tea : it 's Indian , three and sixpenny .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Mine is ten shilling China .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Lor ’ , Julia ! How are you able to afford it ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: A little imagination goes a long way here , you 'll find . Once I tasted it . So now I can always taste it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well ! I wish I 'd known .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Now you do .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But I never tasted tea at more than three-and-six . Had I known , I could have got two ounces of the very best , and had it when ——

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: A lost opportunity . Life is full of them .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then you mean to tell me that if I had indulged more then , I could indulge more now ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Undoubtedly . As I never knew what it was to wear sables , I have to be content with ermine .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Lor ’ , Julia , how paltry !

body.stage: While this conversation has been going on , a gentle old lady has appeared upon the scene , unnoticed and unannounced . One perceives , that is to say , that the high-backed arm-chair beside the fire , sheltered by a screen from all possibility of draughts , has an occupant . Dress and appearance show a doubly septuagenarian character : at the age of seventy , which in this place she retains as the hall-mark of her earthly pilgrimage , she belongs also to the ‘ seventies ’ of the last century , wears watered silk , and retains under her cap a shortened and stiffer version of the side-curls with which she and all ‘ the sex ’ captivated the hearts of Charles Dickens and other novelists in their early youth . She has soft and indeterminate features , and when she speaks her voice , a little shaken by the quaver of age , is soft and indeterminate also . Gentle and lovable , you will be surprised to discover that she , also , has a will of her own ; but for the present this does not show . From the dimly illumined corner behind the lamp her voice comes soothingly to break the discussion .

sp.speaker: OLD LADY
sp.p: My dear , would you move the light a little nearer ? I 've dropped a stitch . LAURAstarting upWhy , Mother dear , when did you come in ? JULIAinterposing with arresting handDo n't ! You must n't try to touch her , or she goes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Goes ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I can n't explain . She is not quite herself . She does n't always hear what one says . LAURAassertivelyShe can hear me .To prove it , she raises her voice defiantly .Ca n't you , Mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: the voice perhaps reminding herJane , dear , I wonder what 's become of Laura , little Laura : she was always so naughty and difficult to manage , so different from Martha — and the rest .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Lor ’ , Julia ! Is it as bad as that ? Mother , ‘ little Laura ’ is here , sitting in front of you . Do n't you know me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Do you remember , Jane , one day when we 'd all started for a walk , Laura had forgotten to bring her gloves , and I sent her back for them ? And on the way she met little Dorothy Jones , and she took her gloves off her , and came back with them just as if they were her own .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What a good memory you have , Mother ! I remember it too . She was an odious little thing , that Dorothy — always so whiney-piney .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: More tea , Laura ?

body.stage: Laura pushes her cup at her without remark , for she has been kept waiting ; then , in loud tones , to suit the one whom she presumes to be rather deaf :

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Mother ! Where are you living now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: I 'm living , my dear .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I said ‘ where ? ’

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: We live where it suits us , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , I was n't addressing myself to you . Mother , where are you living ? . . . Why , where has she gone to ?For now we perceive that this gentle Old Lady so devious in her conversation has a power of self-possession , of which , very retiringly , she avails herself .JULIAimproving the occasion , as she hands back the cup , with that touch of superiority so exasperating to a near relativeNow you see ! If you press her too much , she goes . . . . You 'll have to accommodate yourself , Laura . LAURAimposing her own explanationI think you gave me green tea , Julia . . . or have had it yourself . JULIAknowing betterThe dear Mother seldom stays long , except when she finds me alone .

body.stage: Having insinuated this barb into the flesh of her ‘ dear sister , ’ she takes up her crochet with an air of great contentment . Mrs. James , meanwhile , to make herself more at home , now that tea is finished , undoes her bonnet-strings with a tug , and lets them hang . She is not in the best of tempers .

lg.l: I do n't believe she recognised me . Why did she keep on calling me
‘ Jane ’ ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She took you for poor Aunt Jane , I fancy . LAURAinfuriated at being taken for anyone ‘ poor ’Why should she do that , pray ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Well , there always was a likeness , you know ; and you are older than you were , Laura . LAURAcrushinglyDoes ‘ poor Aunt Jane ’ wear widow 's weeds ?This reminds her not only of her own condition , but of other things as well . She sits up and takes a stiller bigger bite into her new world .Julia ! . . . Where 's William ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I have n't inquired . LAURAself-importance and a sense of duty consuming herI wish to see him .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Better not , as it did n't occur to you before .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Am I not to see my own husband , pray ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: He did n't ever live here , you know .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He can come , I suppose . He has got legs like the rest of us .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Yes , but one can n't force people : at least , not here . You should remember that — before he married you — he had other ties .

body.stage: Mrs. James preserves her self-possession , but there is battle in her eye .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He was married to me longer than he was to Isabel .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: They had children .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I could have had children if I chose . I did n't choose . . . . Julia , how am I to see him ? JULIAwashing her hands of itYou must manage for yourself , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm puzzled ! Here are we in the next world just as we expected , and where are all the —? I mean , ought n't we to be seeing a great many more things than we do ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What sort of things ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , . . . have you seen Moses and the Prophets ?

lg.l: I have n't looked for them , Laura . On Sundays , I still go to hear
Mr. Moore .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That 's you all over ! You never would go to the celebrated preachers . But I mean to .Pious curiosity awakens .What happens here , on Sundays ? JULIAsmilingOh , just the same .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No High Church ways , I hope ? If they go in for that here , I shall go out ! JULIApatiently explanatoryYou will go out if you wish to go out . You can choose your church . As I tell you , I always go to hear Mr. Moore ; you can go and hear Canon Farrar .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Dean Farrar , I suppose you mean .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: He was not Dean in my day .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He ought to have been a Bishop — Archbishop , I think — so learned , and such a magnificent preacher . But I still wonder why we do n't see Moses and the Prophets .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Well , Laura , it 's the world as we knew it — that for the present . No doubt other things will come in time , gradually . But I do n't know : I do n't ask questions . LAURAdoubtfullyI suppose it is Heaven , in a way , though ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Dispensation has its own ways , Laura ; and we have ours . LAURAwho is not going to be theologically dictated to by anyone lower than Dean FarrarJulia , I shall start washing the old china again .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: As you like ; nothing ever gets soiled here .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's all very puzzling . The world seems cut in half . Things do n't seem real .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: More real , I should say . We have them — as we wish them to be .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then why can n't we have our Mother , like other things ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Ah , with persons it is different . We all belong to ourselves now . That one has to accept . LAURAstubbornlyDoes William belong to himself ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I suppose .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It is n't Scriptural !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It 's better .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , do n't be blasphemous !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: To consult William 's wishes , I meant .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But I want him . I 've a right to him . If he did n't mean to belong to me , he ought not to have married me .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: People make mistakes sometimes .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then they should stick to them . It 's not honourable . Julia , I mean to have William ! JULIAresignedlyYou and he must arrange that between you . LAURAmaking a dash for itWilliam ! William , I say ! William !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , Laura , you 'll wake the dead !She gasps , but it is too late : the hated word is out .LAURAas one who will be obeyedWilliam !

body.stage: The door does not open ; but there appears through it the indistinct figure of an elderly gentleman with a weak chin and a shifting eye . He stands irresolute and apprehensive ; clearly his presence there is perfunctory . Wearing his hat and carrying a hand-bag , he seems merely to have looked in while passing .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Apparently you are to have your wish .She waves an introductory hand ; Mrs. James turns , and regards the unsatisfactory apparition with suspicion .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: William , is that you ? WILLIAMnervouslyYes , my dear ; it 's me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Ca n't you be more distinct than that ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Why do you want me ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Have you forgotten I 'm your wife ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I thought you were my widow , my dear .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: William , do n't prevaricate . I am your wife , and you know it .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Does a wife wear widow 's weeds ? A widow is such a distant relation : no wonder I look indistinct .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How did I know whether I was going to find you here ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Where else ? But you look very nice as you are , my dear . Black suits you .

body.stage: But Mrs. James is not to be turned off by compliments .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: William , who are you living with ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: With myself , my dear .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Anyone else ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Off and on I have friends staying .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Are you living with Isabel ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: She comes in occasionally to see how I 'm getting on .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: And how are you ‘ getting on ’ — without me ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Oh , I manage — somehow .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Are you living a proper life , William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Well , I 'm here , my dear ; what more do you want to know ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: There 's a great deal I want to know . But I wish you 'd come in and shut the door , instead of standing out there in the passage .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: The door is shut , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then I do n't call it a door . WILLIAMtrying to make things pleasantWhen is a door not a door ? When it 's a parent .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: William , I want to talk seriously . Do you know that when you died you left a lot of debts I did n't know about ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I did n't know about them either , my dear . But if you had , it would n't have made any difference .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , it would ! I gave you a very expensive funeral .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: That was to please yourself , my dear ; it did n't concern me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Have you no self-respect ? I 've been at my own funeral to-day , let me tell you !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Have you , my dear ? Rather trying , was n't that ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , it was . They 've gone and put me beside you ; and now I begin to wish they had n't !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: Go and haunt them for it !At this Julia deigns a slight chuckle .LAURAabruptly getting back to her ownI had to go into a smaller house , William . And people knew it was because you 'd left me badly off .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: That reflected on me , my dear , not on you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It reflected on me for ever having married you .

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I 've often heard you blame yourself . Well , now you 're free .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm not free .

lg.l: You can be if you like . Had n't you better ?
LAURA
Do n't you see I 'm still in mourning for you ,
William ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I appreciate the compliment , my dear . Do n't spoil it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't be heartless !

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: I 'm not : far from it .He looks at his watch .I 'm afraid I must go now .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why must you go ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: They are expecting me — to dinner .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Who 's ‘ they ’ ?

sp.speaker: WILLIAM
sp.p: The children and their mother . They 've invited me to stay the night .

body.stage: Mrs. James does her best to conceal the shock this gives her . She delivers her ultimatum with judicial firmness .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: William , I wish you to come and live here with me .

body.stage: William vanishes . Mrs. James in a fervour of virtuous indignation hastens to the door , opens it , and calls ‘ William ! ’ but there is no answer .

Julia , meanwhile , has rung the bell . Mrs. James stills stands glowering in the door-way when she hears footsteps , and moves majestically aside for the returned penitent to enter ; but alas ! it is only Hannah , obedient to the summons of the bell . Mrs. James faces round and fires a shot at her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Hannah , you are an ugly woman . JULIAfaint with horrorLaura ! HANNAHimperturbablyWell , Ma'am , I 'm as God made me .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Yes , please , take the tea-things .Sotto voce , as Hannah approaches .I 'm sorry , Hannah !

sp.speaker: HANNAH
sp.p: It does n't matter , Ma'am .She picks up the tray expeditiously and carries it off .

body.stage: Mrs. James eyes the departing tray , and is again reminded of something .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , where is the silver tea-pot ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Which , Laura ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why , that beautiful one of our Mother 's .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: When we shared our dear Mother 's things between us , did n't Martha have it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , she did . But she tells me she does n't know what 's become of it . When I ask , what did she do with it in the first place ? she loses her temper . But once she told me she left it here with you .

body.stage: The fierce eye and the accusing tone make no impression on that cushioned fortress of gentility . With suave dignity Miss Robinson makes chaste denial .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: No . LAURAinsistentYes ; in a box .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: In a box ? Oh , she may have left anything in a box .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It was that box she always travelled about with and never opened . Well , I looked in it oncenever mind how, and the tea-pot was n't there . JULIAgently , making allowanceWell , I did n't look in it , Laura .

body.stage: Like a water-lily folding its petals she adjusts a small shawl about her shoulders , and sinks composedly into her chair .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: The more fool you ! . . . But all the other things she had of our Mother 's were there : a perfect magpie 's nest ! And she , living in her boxes , and never settling anywhere . What did she want with them ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I can n't say , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No — no more can I ; no more can anyone ! Martha has got the miser spirit . She 's as grasping as a caterpillar . I ought to have had that tea-pot .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Because I had a house of my own , and people coming to tea . Martha never had anyone to tea with her in her life — except in lodgings .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: We all like to live in our own way . Martha liked going about .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes . She promised me , after William — I suppose I had better say ‘ evaporated ’ as you wo n't let me say ‘ died ’ — she promised always to stay with me for three months in the year . She never did . Two , and some little bits , were the most . And I want to know where was that tea-pot all the time ? JULIAa little jocoselyNot in the box , apparently . LAURAreturning to her accusationI thought you had it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You were mistaken . Had I had it here , you would have found it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Did Martha never tell you what she did with it ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I never asked , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , if you say that again I shall scream .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Wo n't you take your things off ?

lg.l: Presently . When I feel more at home .
But most of our Mother 's things are here .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Your share and mine .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How did you get mine here ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You brought them . At least , they came , a little before you did . Then I knew you were on your way . LAURAimpressedLor ’ ! So that 's how things happen ?She goes and begins to take a look round , and Julia takes up her crochet again . As she does so her eye is arrested by a little old-fashioned hour-glass standing upon the table from which the tea-tray has been taken , the sands of which are still running .JULIAsoftly , almost to herselfOh , but how strange ! That was Martha 's . Is Martha coming too ?She picks up the glass , looks at it , and sets it down again .LAURAwho is examining the china on a side-tableWhy , I declare , Julia ! Here is your Dresden that was broken — without a crack in it !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: No , Laura , it was yours that was broken .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It was not mine ; it was yours . . . . Do n't you remember I broke it ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: When you broke it you said it was mine . Until you broke it , you said it was yours .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Very well , then : as you wish . It is n't broken now , and it 's mine .

lg.l: That 's satisfactory . I get my own back again . It 's the better one .
lg.stage: ENTER Hannah with a telegram on a salver .
lg.l: HANNAH
lg.stage: in a low voice of mystery
lg.l: A telegram , Ma'am .

body.stage: Julia opens it . The contents evidently startle her , but she retains her presence of mind .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: No answer .

body.stage: EXIT Hannah .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Laura , Martha is coming !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Here ? Well , I wonder how she has managed that !

body.stage: Her sister hands her the telegram , which she reads .
‘ Accident . Quite safe . Arriving by the 6. 30 . ’ Why , it 's after that now ! JULIA ( sentimentally ) . Oh , Laura , only think ! So now we shall be all together again .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , I suppose we shall .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It will be quite like old days . LAURAwarningly , as she sits down again and prepares for narrativeNot quite , Julia .She leans forward , and speaks with measured emphasis .Martha 's temper has got very queer ! She never had a very good temper , as you know : and it 's grown on her .A pause . Julia remains silent .I could tell you some things ; but ——Seeing herself unencouragedoh , you 'll find out soon enough !Then , to stand right with herselfJulia , am I difficult to get on with ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh well , we all have our little ways , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But Martha : she 's so rude ! I can n't introduce her to people ! If anyone comes , she just runs away . JULIAchanging the subjectD'you remember , Laura , that charming young girl we met at Mrs. Somervale 's , the summer Uncle Fletcher stayed with us ? LAURAsnubbinglyI can n't say I do .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I met her the other day : married , and with three children — and just as pretty and young-looking as ever .

body.stage: All this is said with the most ravishing air , but Laura is not to be diverted .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Ah ! I daresay . When Martha behaves like that , I hold my tongue and say nothing . But what people must think , I do n't know . Julia , when you first came here , did you find old friends and acquaintances ? Did anybody recognise you ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: A few called on me : nobody I did n't wish to see .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Is that odious man who used to be our next-door neighbour — the one who played on the ‘ cello — here still ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Mr. Harper ? I see him occasionally . I do n't find him odious .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't you ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It was his wife who was the —— She is n't here : and I do n't think he wants her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where is she ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I did n't ask , Laura .Mrs. James gives a jerk of exasperation , but at that moment the bell rings and a low knock is heard .JULIAecstaticallyHere she is !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , I wonder how it is Martha survived us . She 's much the oldest . JULIApleasantly palpitatingDoes it matter ? Does it matter ?

body.stage: The door opens and in comes Martha . She has neither the distinction of look nor the force of character which belongs to her two sisters . Age has given a depression to the plain kindliness of her face , and there is a harassed look about her eyes . She peeps into the room a little anxiously , then enters , carrying a large flat box covered in purple paper which , in her further progress across the room she lays upon the table . She talks in short jerks and has a quick , hurried way of doing things , as if she liked to get through and have done with them . It is the same when she submits herself to the embrace of her relations .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , so you 've come at last . Quite time , too !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Yes , here I am .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: My dear Martha , welcome to your old home !Embracing her .How are you ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I 'm cold . Well , Laura .

body.stage: Between these two the embrace is less cordial , but it takes place .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How did you come ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't know . JULIAseeing harassment in her sister 's eyeArrived safely , at any rate .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I think I was in a railway accident , but I can n't be sure . I only heard the crash and people shouting . I did n't wait to see . I just put my fingers in my ears , and ran away .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why do you think it was a railway accident ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Because I was in a railway carriage . I was coming to your funeral . If you 'd told me you were ill I 'd have come before . I was bringing you a wreath . And then , as I tell you , there was a crash and a shout ; and that 's all I know about it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Lor ’ , Martha ! I suppose they 'll have an inquest on you . MARTHAstungI think they 'd better mind their own business , and you mind yours !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Laura ! Here we do n't talk about such things . They do n't concern us . Would you like tea , Martha , or will you wait for supper ? MARTHAwho has shaken her head at the offer of tea , and nodded a preference for supperYou know how I 've always dreaded death .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , do n't , my dear Martha ! It 's past .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Yes ; but it 's upset me . The relief , that 's what I can n't get over : the relief !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Presently you will be more used to it .

body.stage: She helps her off with her cloak .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: There were people sitting to right and to left of me and opposite ; and suddenly a sort of crash of darkness seemed to come all over me , and I saw nothing more . I did n't feel anything : only a sort of a jar here .

body.stage: She indicates the back of her neck . Julia finds these anatomical details painful , and holds her hands deprecatingly ; but Laura has no such qualms . She is now undoing the parcel which , she considers , is hers .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I daresay it was only somebody 's box from the luggage-rack . I 've known that happen . I do n't suppose for a minute that it was a railway accident .

body.stage: She unfurls the tissue paper of the box and takes out the wreath .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Why talk about it ?

lg.l: Anyway , nothing has happened to these . ‘ With fondest love from
Martha . ’ H 'm . Pretty !
Martha , would you like to go upstairs with your things ? And you ,
Laura ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I will presently , when I 've got warm .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Not yet . Martha , why was I put into that odious shaped coffin ? More like a canoe than anything . I said it was to be straight .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I 'd nothing to do with it , Laura . I was n't there . You know I was n't .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: If you 'd come when I asked you , you could have seen to it .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: You did n't tell me you were dying .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do people tell each other when they are dying ? They do n't know . I told you I was n't well .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: You always told me that , just when I 'd settled down somewhere else . . . . Of course I 'd have come if I 'd known !testily

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , surely we need n't go into these matters now ! Is n't it better to accept things ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I like to have my wishes attended to . What was going to be done about the furniture ?This to Martha .You know , I suppose , that I left it to the two of you — you and Edwin ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: We were going to give it to Bella , to set up house with .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That 's not what I intended . I meant you to keep on the house and live there . Why could n't you ? MARTHAwith growing annoyanceWell , that 's settled now !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It was n't for Arabella . Arabella was never a favourite of mine . Why should Arabella have my furniture ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Well , you 'd better send word , and have it stored up for you till doomsday ! Edwin does n't want it ; he 's got enough of his own . LAURAin a sleek , injured voiceJulia , I 'm going upstairs to take my things off .

lg.l: Very well , Laura .
lg.stage: And Laura makes her injured exit .
lg.l: So you 've been with Edwin , and his family ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Yes . I 'm never well there ; but I wanted the change .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You mean , you had been staying with Laura ?

lg.l: I always go and stay with her , as long as I can — three months ,
I 'm supposed to . But this year — well , I could n't manage with it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Is she so much more difficult than she used to be ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Of course , I do n't know what she 's like here .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , she has been very much herself — poor Laura !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I know ! Julia , I know ! And I try to make allowances . All her life she 's had her own way with somebody . Poor William ! Of course I know he had his faults . But he used to come and say to me : ‘ Martha , I can n't please her . ’ Well , poor man , he 's at peace now , let 's hope ! Oh , Julia , I 've just thought : whatever will poor William do ? He 's here , I suppose , somewhere ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh yes . He 's here , Martha .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: She 'll rout him out , depend on it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She has routed him out . MARTHAawe-struckHas she ? JULIAshaking her head wiselyWilliam wo n't live with her ; he knows better .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Who will live with her , then ? She 's bound to get hold of somebody .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Apparently she means to live here .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Then it 's going to be me ! I know it 's going to be me ! When we lived here before , it used to be poor Mamma .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: The dear Mother is quite capable of looking after herself , you 'll find . You need n't belong to Laura if you do n't like , Martha . I never let her take possession of me .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: She seems never to want to . I do n't know how you manage it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , we 've had our little tussles . But here you will find it much easier . You can vanish .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I mean — vanish . It takes the place of wings . One does it almost without knowing .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: How do you do it ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You just wish yourself elsewhere ; and you come back when you like .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Have you ever done it ? JULIAwith a world of meaningNot yet .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: She wo n't like it . One does n't belong to one 's self , when she 's about — nor does anything . I 've had to hide my own things from her sometimes .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I should n't wonder .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Do you remember the silver tea-pot ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I 've been reminded of it .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: It was mine , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , of course .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Laura never would admit it was mine . She wanted it ; so I 'd no right to it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I had a little idea that was it .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: For years she was determined to have it : and I was determined she should n't have it . And she did n't have it !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Who did have it ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Henrietta was to . I sent it her as a wedding-present , and told her Laura was never to know . And , as she was in Australia , that seemed safe . Well , the ship it went out in was wrecked — all because of that tea-pot , I believe ! So now it 's at the bottom of the sea !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Destiny !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: She searched my boxes to try and find it : stole my keys ! I missed them , but I did n't dare say anything . I used to wrap it in my night-gown and hide it in the bed during the day , and sleep with it under my pillow at night . And I was so thankful when Henrietta got married ; so as to be rid of it !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Hush !

body.stage: RE-ENTER Mrs. James , her bonnet still on , with the strings dangling , and her cloak on her arm .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia I 've been looking at your room in there . JULIAcoldlyHave you , Laura ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It used to be our Mother 's room .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I do n't need to be reminded of that : it is why I chose it .Rising gracefully from her chair , she goes to attend to the fire .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't you think it would be much better for you to give it up , and let our Mother come back and live with us ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She has never expressed the wish .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Of course not , with you in it .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She was not in it when I came .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: How could you expect it , in a house all by herself ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I gave her the chance : I began by occupying my own room . LAURAself-caressinglyI was n't here then . That did n't occur to you , I suppose ? You seem to forget you were n't the only one .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Kind of you to remind me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Saucy .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Martha , will you excuse me ?Polite to the last , she vanishes gracefully away from the vicinity of the coal-box . The place where she has been stooping knows her no more .LAURArushing round the intervening table to investigateJulia !

body.stage: Martha is quite as much surprised as Mrs. James , but less indignant .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Well ! Did you ever ? LAURAfacing about after vain searchDoes she think that is the proper way to behave to me ? Julia !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: It 's no good , Laura . You know Julia , as well as I do . If she makes up her mind to a thing ——

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes . She 's been waiting here to exercise her patience on me , and now she 's happy ! Well , she 'll have to learn that this house does n't belong to her any longer . She has got to accommodate herself to living with others . . . . I wonder how she 'd like me to go and sit in that pet chair of hers ? JULIAsoftly reappearing in the chair which the ‘ dear Mother ’ usually occupiesYou can go and sit in it if you wish , Laura . LAURAignoring her returnMartha , do you remember that odious man who used to live next door , who played the ‘ cello on Sundays ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Oh yes , I remember . They used to hang out washing in the garden , did n't they ? LAURAvery scandalouslyJulia is friends with him ! They call on each other . His wife does n't live with him any longer .Julia rises and goes slowly and majestically out of the room .LAURAafter relishing what she conceives to be her rout of the enemyMartha , what do you think of Julia ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Oh , she 's —— What do you want me to think ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: High and mighty as ever , is n't she ? She 's been here by herself so long she thinks the whole place is hers .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I daresay we shall settle down well enough presently . Which room are you sleeping in ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Of course , I have my old one . Where do you want to go ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: The green room will suit me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: And Julia means to keep our Mother 's room : I can see that . No wonder she wo n't come and stay .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Have you seen her ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She just ‘ looked in , ’ as Julia calls it . I could see she 'd hoped to find me alone . Julia always thought she was the favourite . I knew better .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: How was she ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Just her old self ; but as if she missed something . It was n't a happy face , until I spoke to her : then it all brightened up . . . . Oh , thank you for the wreath , Martha . Where did you get it ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Emily made it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That fool ! Then she made her own too , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Yes . That went the day before , so you got it in time .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I thought it did n't look up to much .She is now contemplating Emily 's second effort with a critical eye .Now a little maiden-hair fern would have made a world of difference .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't hold with flowers myself . I think it 's wasteful . But , of course , one has to do it . LAURAwith pained regretI 'm sorry , Martha ; I return it — with many thanks .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: What 's the good of that ? I can n't give it back to Emily , now ! LAURAwith quiet griefI do n't wish to be a cause of waste .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Well , take it to pieces , then ; and put them in water — or wear it round your head !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Ten beautiful wreaths my friends sent me . They are all lying on my grave now ! A pity that love is so wasteful ! Well , I suppose I must go now and change into my cap .Goes to the door , where she encounters Julia .Why , Julia , you nearly knocked me down ! JULIAironicallyI beg your pardon , Laura ; it comes of using the same door . Hannah has lighted a fire in your room .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That 's sensible at any rate .

body.stage: EXIT Mrs. James .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Well ? And how do you find Laura ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Julia , I do n't know whether I can stand her .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She has n't got quite — used to herself yet . MARTHAexplosivelyPut that away somewhere !

body.stage: She gives an angry shove to the wreath .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Put it away ! Why ? MARTHAfuriouslyEmily made it : and it did n't cost anything ; and it has n't got any maiden-hair fern in it ; and it 's too big to wear with her cap . So it 's good for nothing ! Put it on the fire ! She does n't want to see it again . JULIAcomprehending the situation , restores the wreath to its boxWhy did you bring it here , Martha ? MARTHAmiserablyI do n't know . I just clung on to it . I suppose it was on my mind to look after it , and see it was n't damaged . So I found I 'd brought it with me . . . . I believe , now I think of it , I 've brought some sandwiches , too .She routs in a small hand-bag .Yes , I have . Well , I can have them for supper . . . . Emily made those too .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Then I think you 'd better let Hannah have them — for the sake of peace . MARTHAwoefullyI thought I was going to have peace here .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: It will be all right , Martha — presently .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Well , I do n't want to be uncharitable ; but I do wish — I must say it — I do wish Laura had been cremated .

body.stage: This is the nearest she can do for wishing her sister in the place to which she thinks she belongs . But the uncremated Mrs. James now re-enters in widow 's cap .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , have you ever seen Papa , since you came here ? JULIAfrigidlyNo , I have not .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Has our Mother seen him ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I have n't ——About to say the forbidden thing , she checks herself .Mamma has not seen him : nor does she know his whereabouts .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Does nobody know ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Nobody that I know of .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , but he must be somewhere . Is there no way of finding him ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Perhaps you can devise one . I suppose , if we chose , we could go to him ; but I 'm not sure — as he does n't come to us .

lg.l: Lor ’ , Julia ! Suppose he should be ——
JULIA
Oh , Laura !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But , Julia , it 's very awkward , not to know where one 's own father is . Do n't people ever ask ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Never , I 'm thankful to say .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Perhaps they know better . LAURAafter a pauseI 'm afraid he did n't lead a good life .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Oh , why can n't you let the thing be ? If you do n't remember him , I do . I was fond of him . He was always very kind to us as children ; and if he did run away with the governess it was a good riddance — so far as she was concerned . We hated her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I wonder whether they are together still . You have n't inquired after her , I suppose ? JULIAluxuriating in her wearinessI — have — not , Laura !

lg.l: Do n't you think it 's our solemn duty to inquire ? I shall ask our
Mother .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I hope you will do nothing of the sort .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: But we ought to know : otherwise we do n't know how to think of him , whether with mercy and pardon for his sins , or with reprobation . MARTHAangrilyWhy need you think ? Why can n't you leave him alone ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: An immortal soul , Martha . It 's no good leaving him alone : that wo n't alter facts .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I do n't think this is quite a nice subject for discussion .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Nice ? Was it ever intended to be nice ? Eternal punishment was n't provided as a consolation prize for anybody , so far as I know .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I think it 's very horrible — for us to be sitting here — by the fire , and —But theology is not Martha 's strong pointOh ! why can n't you leave it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Because it 's got to be faced ; and I mean to face it . Now , Martha , do n't try to get out of it . We have got to find our Father .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I think , before doing anything , we ought to consult Mamma .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Very well ; call her and consult her ! You were against it just now .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I am against it still . It 's all so unnecessary .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Lor ’ , there is Mamma !

body.stage: Old Mrs. Robinson is once more in her place Martha makes a move toward her .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Do n't , Martha . She does n't like to be ——

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: I 've heard what you 've been talking about . No , I have n't seen him . I 've tried to get him to come to me , but he did n't seem to want . Martha , my dear , how are you ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Oh , I 'm — much as usual . And you , Mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Well , what about your Father ? Who wants him ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I want him , Mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: First we want to know what sort of a life he is leading . Then we want to ask him about his will .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , Laura !

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't . I do n't care if he made a dozen .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: So I thought if we all called him . You heard when I called , did n't you ? Oh no , that was William .

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Who 's William ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Did n't you know I was married ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: No . Did he die ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , now , could n't we call him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: I daresay . He wo n't like it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He must . He belongs to us .

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Yes , I suppose — as I would n't divorce him , though he wanted me to . I said marriages were made in Heaven .

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Luckily , they do n't last there .

body.stage: Greatly startled , they look around , and perceive presently in the mirror over the mantelpiece the apparition of a figure which they seem dimly to recognise . A tall , florid gentleman of the Dundreary type , with long side-whiskers , and dressed in the fashion of sixty years ago , has taken up his position to one side of the ormolu clock ; standing , eye-glass in eye , with folded arms resting on the mantel-slab and a stylish hat in one hand , he gazes upon the assembled family with quizzical benevolence .

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: placidlyWhat , is that you , Thomas ? THOMASwith the fashionable lisp of the fifties , always substituting ‘ th ’ for ‘ s ’How do you do , Susan ?

body.stage: There follows a pause , broken courageously by Mrs. James .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Are you my Father ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: I do n't know . Who are you ? Who are all of you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Perhaps I had better explain . This is our dear Mother : her you recognise . You are her husband ; we are your daughters . This is Martha , this is Julia , and I 'm Laura .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Is this true , Susan ? Are these our progeny ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Yes — that is — yes , Thomas .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: I should not have known it . They all look so much older .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Than when you left us ? Naturally !

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Than me , I meant . But you all seem flourishing .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Because we lived longer . Papa , when did you die ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh ! Laura !

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: I do n't know , child .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't know ? How do n't you know ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Because in prisons , and other lunatic asylums , one is n't allowed to know anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: A lunatic asylum ! Oh , Thomas , what brought you there ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: A damned life , Susan — with you , and others .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , Laura , why did you do this ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: If this goes on , I shall leave the room .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where are those others now ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Three of them I see before me . You , Laura , used to scream horribly . When you were teething , I was sleepless . Your Mother insisted on having you in the room with us . No wonder I went elsewhere .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I 'm going !

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Do n't , Martha ! You were the quietest of the lot . When you were two years old I even began to like you . You were the exception .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Have n't you any affection for your old home ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: None . It was a prison . You were the gaolers and the turnkeys . To keep my feet in the domestic way you made me wool-work slippers , and I had to wear them . You gave me neckties , which I would n't wear . You gave me affection of a demanding kind , which I did n't want . You gave me a moral atmosphere which I detested . And at last I could bear it no more , and I escaped . LAURAdeaf to instructionPapa , we wish you and our dear Mother to come back and live with us .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Live with my grandmother ! How could I live with any of you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where are you living ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Ask no questions , and you will be told no lies .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where is she ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Which she ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: The governess .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Which governess ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: The one you went away with .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: D'you want her back again ? You can have her . She 'll teach you a thing or two . She did me .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then — you have repented , Papa ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: God ! why did I come here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. R
sp.p: Yes ; why did you come ? It was weak of you .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Because I never could resist women .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Were you really mad when you died , Papa ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Yes , and am still : stark , staring , raving , mad , like all the rest of you .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I am not aware that I am mad .

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: Then you are a bad case . Not to know it , is the worst sign of all . It 's in the family : you can n't help being . Everything you say and do proves it . . . . You were mad to come here . You are mad to remain here . You were mad to want to see me . I was mad to let you see me . I was mad at the mere sight of you ; and I 'm mad to be off again ! Goodbye , Susan . If you send for me again , I sha n't come !

body.stage: He puts on his hat with a flourish .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Where are you going , Father ?

sp.speaker: THOMAS
sp.p: To Hell , child ! Your Hell , my Heaven !

body.stage: He spreads his arms and rises up through the looking-glass ; you see his violet frock-coat , his check trousers , his white spats , and patent-leather boots ascending into and passing from view . He twiddles his feet at them and vanishes .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And now I hope you are satisfied , Laura ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Where 's Mamma gone ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: So you 've driven her away , too . Well , that finishes it .

body.stage: Apparently it does . Robbed of her parental prey , Mrs. James reverts to the next dearest possession she is concerned about .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Martha , where is the silver tea-pot ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't know , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You said Julia had it .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I did n't say anything of the sort ! You said — you supposed Julia had it ; and I said — suppose she had ! And I left it at that .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia says she has n't got it , so you must have it .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I have n't !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then where is it ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't know any more than Julia knows .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then one of you is not telling the truth . . . .Very judicially she begins to examine the two culprits .Julia , when did you last see it ?

lg.l: On the day , Laura , when we shared things between us . It became
Martha 's : and I never saw it again .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Martha , when did you last see it ?

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I have not seen it — for I do n't know how long .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: That is no answer to my question . MARTHAvindictivelyWell , if you want to know , it 's at the bottom of the sea . LAURAdeliberatelyDo n't talk — nonsense .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: Unless a shark has eaten it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: When I ask a reasonable question , Martha , I expect a reasonable answer .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I 've given you a reasonable answer ! And I wish the Judgment Day would come , and the sea give up its dead , and then ——At the end of her resources , the poor lady begins to gather herself up , so as once for all to have done with it .Now , I am going downstairs to talk to Hannah .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You will do nothing of the kind , Martha .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I 'm not going to be bullied — not by you or anyone .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I must request you to wait and hear what I 've got to say .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: I do n't want to hear it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Julia , are we not to discuss this matter , pray ?

body.stage: Julia , who has her eye on Martha , and is quite enjoying this tussle of the two says nothing .

sp.speaker: MARTHA
sp.p: You and Julia can discuss it . I am going downstairs .

body.stage: Mrs. James crosses the room , locks the door , and , standing mistress of all she surveys , inquires with grim humour .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: And where are you going to be , Julia ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I am where I am , Laura . I 'm not going out of the window , or up the chimney , if that 's what you mean .

body.stage: She continues gracefully to do her crochet .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Now , Martha , if you please . MARTHAgoaded into victoryI 'm sorry , Julia . You 'd better explain . I 'm going downstairs .

body.stage: Suiting the action to the word , she commits herself doggedly to the experiment , descending bluntly and without grace through the carpet into the room below . Mrs. James stands stupent .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Martha ! . . . Am I to be defied in this way ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You brought it on yourself , Laura .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You told her to do it !

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: She would have soon found out for herself .Collectedly , she folds up her work and rises .And now , I think , I will go to my room and wash my hands for supper .

body.stage: As she makes her stately move , her ear is attracted by a curious metallic sound repeated at intervals . Turning about , she perceives , indeed they both perceive , in the centre of the small table , a handsome silver tea-pot which opens and shuts its lid at them , as if trying to speak .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Oh , look , Laura ! Martha 's tea-pot has arrived .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: She told a lie , then .

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: No , it was the truth . She wished for it . The sea has given up its dead .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then now I have got it at last !But , as she goes to seize the disputed possession , Martha rises through the floor , grabs the tea-pot , and descends to the nether regions once more .LAURAglaring at her sister with haggard eyeJulia , where are we ?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean , Laura .She reaches out a polite hand .The key ?

body.stage: Mrs. James delivers up the key as one glad to be rid of it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What is this place we 've come to ? JULIApersuasivelyOur home .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I think we are in Hell ! JULIAgoing to the door , which she unlocks with soft triumphWe are all where we wish to be , Laura .A gong sounds .That 's supper .The gong continues its metallic bumbling .Julia departs , leaving Mrs. James in undisputed possession of the situation she has made for herself .CURTAIN Printed by Hazell , Watson & Viney , Ld ., London and Aylesbury .
